title: Might Trump intervene militarily in Pakistan-Afghanistan conflict? | DW News
description:
Afghanistan's Taliban rulers say they are willing to negotiate after Pakistan bombed cities including the capital Kabul and Kandahar. Pakistan accuses Afghanistan of harbouring militants responsible for cross-border attacks inside Pakistan. The bombing marks a major escalation of a long-running border dispute. Pakistan’s defense minister has warned the situation amounts to "open war" between the neighbors. 

Chapter Breakdown 
0:00 Pakistan-Afghanistan conflict
3:34 Moeed Yusuf, Vice Chancellor, Beaconhouse National University, former national security advisor to Pakistan's prime minister, on whether US is likely to intervene

title: What's behind the recent AI market jitters? | DW News
description:
IBM, Crowdstrike, Salesforce — Why have traditional tech darlings suddenly slipped into the crosshairs of investors worried about AI disruption? How much of the concern is merited, and how much is overreaction? DW speaks with Wedbush Securities' Dan Ives over recent turbulence in the markets.

title: US, Israel strikes on Iran: Can a regime change be achieved by military force? | DW News
description:
Israel and the US have launched a series of coordinated attacks on Iran. 

Explosions have been heard in the capital Tehran, and local media are reporting nationwide missile strikes. Witnesses say they've seen smoke rising near the offices of the Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who has not been seen in public for days. Iran's Revolutionary Guard says it has launched a first wave of drones and missiles targeting Israel – and US bases elsewhere in the region. 

In Israel, sirens have been ringing out across Jerusalem, where authorities have issued "an extremely serious alert". These are pictures of Jerusalem that you're seeing now. Israel's defense minister has declared a state of emergency for the whole country. 

00:00 US "Operation Epic Fury" against Iran
00:48 Misha Komadovsky, DW Correspondent
05:50 Hans-Jakob Schindler, Iran expert
12:40 Shani Rozanes, DW Middle East analyst

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

title: The consequences of Chinese state subsidies | To the Point
description:
First China, then the United States — the German Chancellor is visiting the world’s two biggest power centers, aiming to secure maximum benefits for Germany’s economy and its geopolitical position.
China remains the key market for Germany, with bilateral trade surpassing €250 billion in 2025. Yet Chancellor Merz faces a challenge: German products are losing ground, and he needs to boost their appeal in a highly competitive Chinese market.
Next stop: the United States, Germany’s second‑largest trading partner. But the long-standing transatlantic partnership has hit turbulence. President Trump’s tariff policies have strained relations, causing trade volumes to shrink by around 5 percent. So the big question is: Where should Germany place its bets? Is China the more promising partner — or do the US offer the stronger long‑term alliance? In this video, we explore Germany’s strategic dilemma between Washington and Beijing: Who is the better partner for the future?

Our guests: Thorsten Benner, Global Public Policy Institute (GPPi)
Noah Barkin, Rhodium Group 
Meredith Crowley, Professor of Economics University of Cambridge

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

title: Iran retaliatory strikes on US bases in the UAE, Bahrain, Qatar, Jordan and Kuwait | DW News
description:
US, Israel strike Iran – What we know so far: 

The US and Israel have launched a series of coordinated strikes on Iran, which the Pentagon is calling Operation Epic Fury.

President Donald Trump says major combat operations aim to annihilate Iran's naval sites, and has vowed the regime will never have a nuclear weapon.

Iran's Revolutionary Guard says it has retaliated by launching drones and missiles against Israel and US bases in the region. 

Blasts have been heard in the United Arab Emirates, Jordan, Bahrain and Kuwait.

Blasts have been reported in countries across the Gulf as Iran launches retialiatory strikes. Saudi Arabia says Iran carried out attacks on the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Qatar, Jordan and Kuwait. 

There have been reports of explosions and sirens across the Gulf region as missile defenses spring into action. Iran always threatened to target US bases in the region if Washington launched an attack on its territory.

00:00 Iran launches retaliatory attacks
01:09 Anjana Sankar, Journalist

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

title: Bill Clinton: I saw nothing and I did nothing wrong | DW News
description:
Former US President Bill Clinton has told members of Congress that he 'did nothing wrong' in his ties with Jeffrey Epstein. Clinton gave a deposition to members of a congressional committee at a closed door session in New York state. He released a statement ahead of that, saying he had seen no sign of the abuse carried out by Epstein.  Bill Clinton is not accused of any wrongdoing in the case. His statement followed  that of his wife, Hillary Clinton, who on Thursday told the panel she does not recall ever meeting Epstein.

00:00 Bill Clinton testifies in Epstein investigation
01:25 Benjamin Alvarez Gruber, DW Correspondent
